spans.text: Umiri led Taki towards the beach. Arriving at the stone steps leading down to the beach, Umiri simply took off her boots and socks, and placed them aside. Taki silently followed suit.
The two walked barefoot on the gravel.
(The gravel on the steps is so rough...)
(...It's much better on the beach.)
(The sand is very fine. It sinks in shallowly and wraps around my feet, it's cool, not cold.)
Taki, let's walk towards the sea.
Okay.
Swish, swash, the regular sound of the tide echoed.

Along with the sound of the tide, the white foam soaked onto the beach, cut off by the ankles, and then reconnected into a complete line, continuing to advance until it was completely swallowed by the black beach.
The next time the tide sounded, a new white line was gathering.
(...The seawater in winter is also warm.)
Taki, watch your step. Don't underestimate the rising tide at night.
—Everyone who patrols or is on duty on the beach will advise this.
Huh? Then why did you lead me so deep?
If you're scared, you can hold my hand.
Let me remind you, Ms. Yahata, you're only two centimeters taller than me.
Umiri suddenly restrained her smile and looked straight at the beach ahead.
Taki followed her line of sight and saw a semi-transparent shadow on the shallows, its outline gently floating with the tide.
(That is...)
There are jellyfish ahead, let's go around them.
Jellyfish?
There will be jellyfish washed ashore by the waves. They may be poisonous.
Okay.
(Is that big shadow the jellyfish?)
(...It's stranded, which means it will die later, right.)
Umiri, will this jellyfish be carried back by the waves?
Maybe it can, but it's difficult.
It was washed to the shallows, and small waves can't carry it away anymore.
Then will it die.
It may already be dead.
Also, jellyfish are very soft, and it's difficult to push it back with tools.
Tools like wooden sticks may poke into its body and tear it apart.
......Have you tried it?
Yeah.
Umiri, every time you come here alone, you walk along the beach like this.
Don't you have the urge to "just be taken away by the sea"?
(Every step is not solid. Dim moonlight, soft sand, unbalanced buoyancy.)
(Even with you by my side... when going deep into the sea like this, we are already walking on a very dangerous line.)
I do.
If it could take me away, I probably wouldn't struggle. But I won't deliberately go to a more dangerous place.
Because that wouldn't be fate, but just "giving up."
Umiri, do you believe in fate?
I believe in fate.
But I only accept uncertain fate.
If it's uncertain, is it still fate?
(The countdown of fate is accurate to the second.)
Why not?
Fate, in my eyes, is just where a person's life trajectory leads.
What if all of this is predetermined by some existence?
Then I would deny that existence.
My fate belongs only to myself.

I accept that when I come here to relax, I might be swept away by the sea due to an accident. But if one day, that kind of existence you mentioned appears and confidently declares that I will drown in the sea...
Then I would rather never come to the beach again.
But, what if you find that you still need to go to the beach due to force majeure?
That's what they write in books. Like Oedipus, in the end he still unintentionally killed his father and married his mother, doing the evil deeds in the prophecy.
If I find that I still need to go to the beach due to force majeure, then I will end my life in that moment beforehand.
Although Oedipus did the evil deeds in the prophecy, he never knew about this prophecy before that.
He never had a chance to truly fight against fate, he was just being played with.
Then I think there's not much difference between that and being framed by a villain. I will not recognize this clear "malice" as "my fate."
On the contrary, my fate is to fight against it until the very last moment.
Malice?
(I shouldn't continue asking, we've talked enough about this.)
(But, I want to know your answer.)
If the malice you mentioned, Umiri, slyly doesn't tell you in advance, but just silently plots a surprise attack.
And when it succeeds, it appears like a villain and shouts: "This is all my plan. This is fate."
What should I do then.
Isn't it simple?
Just have a clear conscience before death.
If it's a mistake, then atone for it; if it's a price, then repay it. If direct death comes, then it doesn't matter even more.
The tide once again passed over the ankles.
Umiri's words fell into the sound of the tide, and were taken back to the depths of the sea by the receding waves.
Taki looked out at the sea in the direction where the waves receded.
(...If I die here.)
(Would it also be a confrontation against that countdown?)
Taki, what's wrong, with that expression.
I was just thinking, facing the sea...
(And that countdown.)
I'm so small.
I'm not reconciled.
Why can't I be more powerful.
(If I were more powerful, would everything be different.)
(If I could keep making popular songs that move everyone...)
(Wouldn't MyGO!!!!! commercialize naturally, and wouldn't everyone have more reasons to be together...)
(Even if this countdown suddenly appeared to judge me, I could...)
I worry that I cannot die with a clear conscience.
......You're just too tired, Taki.
I brought you here to relax.
But your expression seems even more heavy now.
Yes, we are small and lack power.
But you're not the type of person who would care about that, Taki. You know that your strength is limited, and you will worry and get angry because you didn't do things well.
But after the negative emotions dissipate, you will continue to work hard without distraction, and firmly produce one achievement after another.
You like that, very shining.
I don't understand why you're acting so anxious.
Just consider tonight as my reservation, relax a little more.
Come with me.
Umiri directly turned around and walked towards the long stone steps beside the beach.
Taki followed a beat later.
Across the entire beach, the sea that seemed to swallow everything just now turned back into a scenic view, appearing docile and harmless.
The two sat side by side on the cold stone steps.
Ever since I saw Taki's appearance of being depressed, working hard, and being happy for the band since high school, I would think "that's really good."
When you said "a band for life," I was very surprised and envious at the time.
I wish I could join this band—I thought so. So when you invited me, I was actually very happy.
However, your story is much more complicated than I imagined, and joining you is not as simple as supporting the band and filling the gap.
Then it's not my home after all.
...Ah, it's that time.
High school, I didn't realize it was so far away.
(...So nostalgic.)
Thinking about it now, I really handled things so badly at that time...
Even my sister is too lazy to make fun of me to this day...
It must have caused you trouble too, sorry.
It's nothing. I'm very happy that you thought of inviting me.
...I feel like I've said a lot of things I wouldn't usually say.
Indeed, it's the first time I've heard you say these things.
I brought you to such a far place, where you can't catch crabs or dig for shells.
I have to provide some service.
Service?
Chat service.
Oh, and I can also provide a handshake service. Usually fans have to buy handshake tickets to get it, but it's free now.
Do you need it?
No way!
I don't remember Ave Mujica taking the idol route?
Luckily, I have a backup plan.
Huh? What trick is it this time?
Wait a moment.
Wait...
(...She just left...)
She actually left me here alone.
(...Before, did the waves sound like this?)
(The barbaric sound like a beast, the horrifying, life-knocking rhythm... the darkness and cold that choose to devour people.)
(Is this the "death" that Umiri was talking about?)
(The melody hasn't changed, why does it feel so different.)
The sound of swishing and swashing water always echoed regularly.
In the ambiguous world, only a vague flow of white hints at where the boundary of everyday life ends.
Sorry to keep you waiting.
Huh?!
(When did she come back, wait, on my head...?)
Taki subconsciously reached out and grabbed the weight on top of her head.
Familiar square cardboard packaging, the special room temperature heating of winter vending machine drinks.
Ah.
(So warm.)
Have you relaxed now?
Swish, the waves fell on the beach again.
The white waves pushed deep in one go.
(The sound of the waves has become quiet.)
As expected, this is indispensable.
...Where did you buy it? I didn't see it.
Umiri sat down with her own drink.
There's a vending machine if you walk a little further ahead.
Drink this first to warm up your body, you worked hard tonight.
...Hmm?
Taki grabbed Umiri's wrist.
It's not fair that you just put the drink on my head.
Indeed.
Taki took the drink with the Panda logo from her friend, and Umiri straightened her back slightly.
The shadow of Taki standing up was cast on Umiri, and then, Umiri felt a warm weight on her head.
Please enjoy.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
The two who have entered society enjoyed the warm drinks that were so familiar in high school on the cold beach in the dark night.
At this time, a dazzling white light flashed in the corner of their vision.
Hmm!?
(Light? A searchlight?)
It's nine o'clock.
The contact is...?
The lighthouse here starts at nine o'clock in winter.
The first time I found out about this, I was just as surprised as you are now.
And then, I was moved at that time.
Moved?
Yes. Moved.
No matter when, encountering light in the darkness, a strong light that can pass through the darkness, I will be moved.
Seeing this light on the beach, I am reminded of "hope" and the brilliance of human nature that "effort brings hope to others"... or "love".
I know the light of the lighthouse is just work. But if you only look at the world from this perspective, isn't it too boring.
I make music to not live so boringly.
You're still so cool.
You too.
Me?
(I can't say lines like that.)
My life is mostly repeating work that may seem boring to others day and night.
In front of the workstation, experimenting, discarding, and rewriting one beat at a time.
I won't go to different bands, and I won't take the time to speed out of the city to see the sea.
I wouldn't use a shovel to look for small crabs, and I wouldn't be overwhelmed by the lighthouse.
(Even, I can't determine whether the songs I'm making now are "not boring.")
Then Taki, do you think your life is boring?
.........Of course not.
Searching for answers in music, and also shouting my own answers with music.
Just so I don't live in a limited way.
If I can find the light of the lighthouse, or become the light of others, it doesn't matter if I am taken away by the deep sea one day.
...In the band, many people have this idea. Just because they are shy or for other reasons, they didn't say it.
But music has a soul, and music will express for those who are not good at speaking. Even this sea, its voice has a soul.
Taki, I have listened to every song of MyGO.
I have heard your shouts countless times—I am confident that I will not misunderstand your thoughts.
So I'm a little scared.
Taki, will you disappear?
Maybe I will disappear.
And then one night, when you're crying, Umiri, I'll knock on your door and scare you like a ghost.
(Maybe a real ghost.)
(If you really get scared, then please bear with it, Umiri.)
Okay, then see you on Halloween.
...You always say something shocking.
Taki started it first.
I can't argue with that.
I will not disappear.
I promise.
(I will definitely break that damn countdown.)
The light of the lighthouse swept over the two again.
Swish, the monotonous sound of the waves heralds the yachts waiting for the lighthouse to guide them in the distance.
I think your words are more touching than this light, Umiri.
Honestly, I never thought you would say these things to me.
This light can move me because it reminds me of you guys, Taki.
(...Why are you saying this suddenly.)
Ahem.
So, you brought me here to show me the lighthouse?
No.
I said from the beginning that we are always at the destination.
Because there was no final answer from the beginning.
Aimless...
Yes, aimless.
Speaking of this... Taki, you also have a car, aren't you curious about whether tonight's itinerary is reasonable?
Tonight's... itinerary?
From Tokyo to Kamakura, the national highway you chose is about sixty kilometers one way... it's a bit remote, and there are almost no gas stations...
Wait, is there enough gas in the motorcycle? I don't want to push the car with you to...
Don't worry, I always fill up the car whenever I have time.
Just for a trip like today's, impulsive and aimless.
You're always prepared to go on a long trip, huh...
You really are, planning to mess around.
Do I need to be this surprised, your expression is like seeing Spider-Man fight Iron Man.
Spider-Man can't fight Iron Man! They seem to be... father and son?
Wait, stop right there, why are you suddenly bringing up old movie memes?
Don't you think that "a movie that we weren't interested in but went to see for the first time together because of the trend" is very memorable?
It feels very much like a high school girl.
...Is it possible that we were high school girls at that time.
Actually, I think the matcha mille-feuille we ate that day was more memorable, it was the first time I didn't think the taste of matcha was so bad... and it had a premonition meaning.
Premonition...?
Ah... Is Raana's studies going well?
Yes, it will go well. She promised.
That's really rare.
Probably the same as always.
(...It's time to care about her.)
By the way, I know you have her contact information, don't tell her that I looked for you twice to drink to complain... no, to dispel my depression.
I'll pretend I didn't hear that.
I'd rather you pretend I didn't complain at all.

From band activities to members' trivia, from high school memories to university life, from Enoshima to the Arakawa Line, from the imported cars of Chunfeng Dynamics to Speyside whiskey... the topics drifted further and further away like being taken away by the tide.

Old stories that have been talked and laughed about hundreds of times, news that hasn't had time to be shared, how Uika taught them how to find other stars through Sirius and Orion... just thinking about it, they blurted out.
Taki vaguely had the urge to ask herself what she was doing. Because since she got on the motorcycle, all the conversations have been so aimless—just like this journey itself.
But the strange thing is that the notes in her heart didn't seem to be silenced by distraction, but were jumping with joy.
Speaking of which, planned messing around is still messing around, and no matter what, wearing a crop top and speeding in winter is still too much.
Didn't Sakiko tell you to pay attention to your health?
Has Taki listened to Ave Mujica's songs?
Huh? Of course, I've listened to all of them, what does that have to do with...
So Taki thinks our band is active for the goal of God's redemption, or healthy living to a hundred years old and going to heaven peacefully?
......If I had to choose one, I think your chances of going to hell are higher.
It seems that Taki has also fully experienced the soul of our band, very rock, isn't it.
Maybe.
The light of the lighthouse alternated between strong and weak like beating a rhythm for a few seconds, indicating that it was the hour.
The trip is coming to an end.
Out of five points, what score would you give to this aimless trip?
What is this again.
A post-activity questionnaire, each questionnaire is a valuable suggestion on how to improve the next activity.
By the way, my personal score for this time is 3 points.
Hmm? That's not a high score.
1 point is deducted because it might be better to come in the afternoon, and there could be a crab digging and shell picking session.
You're still thinking about that...
1 point is deducted because I'm not sure if this trip was forced or not.
Today's climate may not be suitable for going to the beach.
...The tour guide himself still unilaterally said a lot of things.
It wasn't forced, and it wasn't unilateral.
If I had to say, it would probably be 4.5 points, 1 point deducted for that weird movie meme you made earlier.
...But seriously, who did you learn that corny metaphor from?
Hachiko... Uika.
I'm too tired to complain tonight.
Wait, I have one sentence left—
Your algorithm exceeds five points.
Because this was a perfect trip and beyond.
...Welcome Ms. Taki to visit our company again.
